_header: The swain he proffers his sword with swithe sore sighs
Note: Cf. 959 for another fragment of the same original. Translates lines 2393-8 and 2117-25; formerly included in 6306.
_description: Two fragmentary extracts from an alliterative translation of Les Voeux du Paon of Jacques d’Longuyon — 14 lines

Fairhurst.First Lines:
De swanyn he profres his swerde with swithe sore siches And danne
                    biddes de beurn bi alle his goddes…
Fairhurst.Last Lines:
…Of dis metere & of mor minegen i thenke And carpe to do
                    conquerour of i come dennes
Fairhurst.Editions:
Turville-Petre,  Thorlac. 
             “A Lost Alliterative Alexander Romance.” 
             Review of English Studies
         n.s. 30 (1979): 306-7: 306.
